meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh oh, can you guys still hear me?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Xiao Su (UIUC)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yep.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's too many windows here. Um, uh so some key thoughts, um, some of you have been relatively quiet here. Uh I would point to Caleb and Oana. Uh what what are what are some uh what what did you take away from this conversation?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Oana Luca, CU Boulder
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think we have an interfacial challenge. I think there's aspects of um capture, conversion and putting everything together that um I think theory can uh support. And um yeah, it was a great food for thought conversation in terms of um you know, um what products we could make and what for for me since that's what all I think about is what products we can make at what temperature and what the mechanism is. Um I don't know, Caleb.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Caleb Hill (Wyoming)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh I mean, for me a whole bunch of shit about scalability that I never thought about. Um because I work much more at the fundamental level of trying to figure out how to probe little nano sized domains of catalyst and things like that. So lots of interesting stuff for me to think about moving forward.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: Katie, what'd you take away from all this?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katie Knowles (U. Rochester)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry, I lost track of my zoom windows looking at the slide. Um I'm thinking about the that there's lots of different pathways for CO2 reduction, like lots of different electrochemical processes to think about. And I don't think that there's like a uh one size fits all. I think ultimately going to have to be doing a lot of these different things in parallel, whether some some conversion just for storage to get us to negative and others for um sort of like the value added um products. So.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: Other thoughts?

meeting_annotations.speaker: MARCEL SCHREIER - UW Madison
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I I I feel I I just generally feel that um in all these discussions that um there are still too many directions sort of like uh uh to essentially really say like where where where is the use of electrochemistry going, right? So so maybe electrochemistry is at the heart of all the negative emissions technologies that that is a possibility but it would really help me to know like kind of where what what is the consensus like where where will electrochemistry come in and play like the dominant role. Maybe at this stage this is too early to say that and we are in a phase where we're kind of like scouting around and trying to figure out like how how we're solving this problem in the first place, right? But I I generally think um yeah, I I really would like to figure out um like where uh where we are where where electrochemistry is is is making an impact and whether there are like a certain set of categories maybe electro catalysis, electrochemical capture. Um I don't know, we don't have much time left but if if anyone uh wants to chime in, I would be interested.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Xiao Su (UIUC)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm just going to say from uh oh, sorry.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: No, go ahead.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Xiao Su (UIUC)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh yeah, I was just going to say from uh again from a sort of a more engineering perspective here. I think that uh we want at some point the answer the the sort of judge be industry and the commercial um um entity actually implements it. I I think that, you know, for a lot of technologies, you have all these competitive things and then it's only becomes like a solution when it's implemented by industry. So I don't know if we can come up with an answer because we're developing the methods. I think that um the judge at the end is society has to take one of these systems and implement it. And uh so I don't know if electro catalysis is implemented in industry um uh right now for carbon capture in any way. I think the startups are really the the interface. So um that's my opinion.

meeting_annotations.transcript: So I I think there is a a potential real real driver there and if you were if you replace fossil hydrocarbon use then you have that's where your climate impact comes from.
